div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE

The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.
div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: THE ANGLO-EGYPTIAN BANK, LIMITED.
div.p: LONDON, PARIS ALEXANDRIA, CAIRO MALTA, GIBRALTAR, TANTAH, AND PORT SAID.
Subscribed Capital JS1.500,000
Reserve Fund... 500,000
The Anglo-Egyptian Bank. Limited, undertakes every description of banking business on the most favourable conditions.
Current accounts opened with commercial homes and private individuals in conformity with the custom of Bankers.
Fixed deposits for one year certain received at 8 per cent. per annum. Deposits at interest for shorter periods are also received at rates to be agreed upon.
Letters of Credit for the use of travellers are issued payable in all parts of the World.
Approved bills discounted.
Bills, documentary invoices, etc, collected.
Drafts and telegraphic transfers issued payable all over the World.
Foreign exchange bought and sold.
Advances made upon approved securities and upon cotton, cotton-seed, sugar and other merchandise.
The purchase and sale of stocks and shares on the London Stock Exchange; and on the local and Continental Bourses, undertaken.

Customers can deposit their valuables, bonds, etc., for safe custody in the Bank's fire-proof strong-rooms, and the Bank will attend to the collection of the coupons and drawn bonds so deporited as they fall due.
Mercantile credits issued.
Annuities, pensions, dividends, etc., collected.
All farther particulars and information can be obtained on application.
The officers and clerks of the Bank are pledged to secrecy as to the transactions of customers. 18-9-905

div.head: AKABA IN ANCIENT TIMES
div.p: AKABA IN ANCIENT TIMES. Political events often bring into prominence the most out-of-the way places on this earth. Pendji and Fashoda ware little heard of until they became the scenes of events of serious and important political incidents. Now Aka bah, an out-of-the-way place-town it can hardly be called, for it a cluster of houses with an inferior bazaar which nestles under the walls of the Turkish fort—becomes the scene of a political episode which raises it in importance. The dispute over the Egyptian-Turkish frontier, which is now exercising the minds of politicians, is but the latest phase of a problem which has existed for thousands of years. As the Egyptians and the Turks now dispate over the line of demarcation, so the Assyrians and the Pharaohs disputed over the same matter in the early years of the eighth century before our era.

The neighbourhood of the Wady El Arish, the western terminus of the somewhat arbitrarily drawn frontier, has been the soene of two or more battles in ancient times which have had considerable influence on future history. In B.C. 714, Sargon, the victor of S .maria, defeated the Egyptian, or rather Ethiopian, Army at Raphia, betwren Gaza and El Ariah; while, twelve years latter, Sennacherib overthrew the Syro Egyptian allies in the battle of Eltekeh, followed by the siege of Jerusalem, and the submission of Hezekiah. The frontier line in dispute passes across the limestone plateau of Et-Tih, the desert of the wanderings, and terminates at Akabah. Two roadways cross this arid dersert, which resembles the Sahara in its barrenness, deserted by man and beast. The first is the Haj, or Pilgrim, road, which started from Ismailia, or Kantara, “the bridde,” and terminated at Akabah, where the caravans halted prior to continuing their weary jonrney along the coast of Arabia toJeddah and Mecca. The road is now but little used, and consequently, the inhabitants of Akabah do not reap the rich harvest they formerly did. A second road of much greater importance and antiqnity is the Syrian road, which terminates at Gazs. This is one of the oldest trade routes in the world, being the channel by which the wealth of Midian Edom and Yemen was conveyed to Syria and Egypt. It was in use long before the time of Solomon, and was the route by which the Midianite merchants carried Joseph into Egypt. It was certainly used by traders and others as early as the Twelfth Egyptian Dynasty, and was the route by which Sinuit fled to Midian in the reign of Amen-em-hat III. It is frequently referred to in the Minean inscriptions, and in a text of the Persian period there is a reference to the deliverence of some merchants from the King of Persia beyond the river, probably Cambyses, then advancing on Egypt.

During the Crusades it was in their hands, and Rainald du Chatillon was in 1182 Governor of Akabah. The town of Akabah is also of historical importance, though little remains to it now. Situated at the head of the gulf to which it gives its name, which is to be identified as the Biblical Gulf of Elsk, it represents the emporium which Solomon founded on the Red Sea for trade with the mythical Ophir. Forming as it does the terminus of the great fault or gorge which runs from the north of Palestine south, and includes in its depression the Jordan valley, the Lake of Galilee, the Dead Sea—with the rocky channel of the Wady Akabah—it represents the outlet, no doubt, of some great river bed which in far remote ages had its month in the gulf. The surface water which rolls down from the slopes of El Shara and the Wady Akabah brings sufficient nourishment for a fringe of palm groves and vegetation to clothe the shore, and to form a pleasing variation to the arid desert and glaring rocks which are all around.

The prosperity of the part in ancient times has now disappeared, and indeed there is considerable doubt as to it having existed. Of the travellers who have visited the site Ruppell, Burkbart, Belle, and later Sir R. (ENDED RIGHT HERE) Burton and Mr/Wilfrid Blunt, none of them appear to have been able to find any trace of really anoient ruins. The only remains of antiqnity are found on the island of Farnn—Pharaoh’i island, near Waait—bnt this, as now seen, does not appear to be older than Roman times , but oertaiuly oooupied and enlarged in crusading tilhea, and afterwards oooupied by Salad in, who in 1167 a.d. is said to have driven tbs Infidels oat by carrying ships on oamel back - from Cairo. If the rains are not antique, there is a decided evidenoe of raoial antiquity iu tbs inhabitants of this aod the opposite coast They differ entirely from the $edouin, being lighter in oolonr, more aotive, and indeed might be oonsidered to have some Somali affinities. They are found all along the Arabian ooaat north of Jeddah. Their sonroe of livelihood is ostensibly pearl and ooral fishing, bnt many a orew of coasting vessels has fonnd that they make first olase pirates. Only a few months ago a native dhow from Suakin was wrecked on this ooast, stripped of everything valuable, and the orew are still miaeing. Daring recent years Akabah has revived little owing to the completion of the Da- aaoua Maan railway, whioh it is intendod to extend to this town ; and its forerunner, the telegraph, has reached it already. The Turks daring the interminable Yemen rebellion have oonveyed troops to Maan by rail and marched them down to Akabah, taking them thence by sea to the seat of war. The reported 3,000 men at Akabah now ia probably a great exaggeration of nomberi, for they would soon at the inhabitants ont of house and Some. The troops here are probably waiting oouvey- ance to Yemen. Of the fort at Dliaba or Tabah, there appears to have been do knowledge until recently, and it does not appear on any map, not even on the Egyptian official map, and I aminolined to agree with Mr. W. S. Blunt, who regards it as a very modorn oonstrnotioo. One word of warning to thoso who imagine a great future for this region. We hoar oonatantly of gold aud oopper uiinde In these regions, and ol great development*. but in a land whioh lacks all the essential* of oommeroial snooses—water, wood, ooal, and, above all, labour—snob mining operations are impossible, and in addition tho natives sro trne sons of I-hmael, with their hand against every man aud every man’s band against them, ("The Glob*").

div.head: TO-DAY'S TELEORAM
AMERICA'S MOST APPALLING DISASTER
FRISCO FIRE UNDER CONTROL
RELIEF MEASURES
div.p: New York, April 21.
The Mayor of San Francisoo has issued a proclamation to the effeot that the fire is under control.
The American insurance companies have decided to pay all claims. It is believed that altogether 110,000,000 dollars will be paid to San Francisco policy-holders. (Reuter)
New York, April 21.

At San Francisco the homeless are enoamp- ed in the parks and open spaces, the wealthy alongside the poorest : all efforts are concentrated on sheltering and rationing : the people are very orderly : gre\t hopes are entertained of saving the snbnrb called Western Addition and northwards to Presidio, bat the fire along the Waterfront is still uncontrolled and fanned by a strong northwest wind which threatens the ferry, the only means of egress from the city. The broken watermains are being restored. Operatio stars, inolnding Signor Caruso and Sembrich, escaned in night attire, one artist barefooted and in pyjamas olutohing his violin.

President Roosevelt recommended Congress to vote an additional 1,500,000 dollars for the relief of the sufferers at San Francisco, as it appears that the disaster is the most appalling one in the history of the country. All the mails in the Post Office were saved and 11 of the clerks were extricated alive but unconscious, having been foodless and waterless for three days. (Reuter
New York, April 22.
The fire along the waterfront at San Francisco is under control: the ferry is safe and trains are beginning to run. (Reuter)

div.head: FRENCH STRIKE DISTUBANCES
PITCHED BATTLE WITH TROOPS
div.p: Lille, April 2*.
Lille, April 2*.

A regular pitched battle has taken place beweeu 6,000 strikers and a detachment of Dragoons, between Denain and Havelny: the * Dragoons were compelled to release the prisoners: two captains and 10 troopers were wounded. The strikers then proceeded toHave- luy and sacked the houses. (Reuter)
Paris, April 21.
The situation in North France continues to be serious : disturbances have taken place at Domain and LieviD, where strikers erected barricades. (Reuter)
Lorient, April 21.
The strike is general. Disturbances have taken place. Several persons have been injured. (Havas)
Lille, April 22.
Eight thousand more reinforcements have arrived at Lens : there are now 210,000 troops in the mining distiict. (Reuter)

(Jfenter) Athens, April 22. After a speech by Prince Constantine, the King of Greece inaugurated the Olympic Games. King Edward wore the uniform of a Greek admiral, whioh title had been conferred on him by King George. The crowd was innumerable. (Havas'

The death of an Englishwoman was the subject of the investigations of a court of enquiry helcHhis morning at the British Consulate at Alexandria. The deceased’s name was Jessie Briwno and Bhe was a stewardess on board of the Khedivial Mail’s S.S. Assouan. She died frepa_t>iing corrosive sublimate but whether intentionally or not is as yet unknown, for the Court was still sitting as we went to press. Mohamed Aly Industrial School. It will he a very fine building and should go a very long way to affording the native youths ot Alexandria every aid towards a complete technioal edsca- tioual equipment.

div.head: DUKE OF THE ABRUZZI AT SUEZ.
(FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT.)
div.p: Suez, Sunday. The Duke of the Abrozzi and suite were among the passengers by the German steamer Burgemeister, which sailed from Suez last night. The expedition of the Duke, consisting ot naval and military officers and Alpine guides, will land at Mcmbrsa and thence proceed throogh the centre of Africa to asoend Mount RuveDzore, which so far has been unexplored.

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: H.H. the Khedive left Alexandria for Cairo on Saturday evening. His Highness came in to Abdeen Palace to-day from Koubbeh and presided at the Council of Ministers. The Khedive will hold a final reception at Cairo prior to his Highness’s departure for Alexandria on Saturday next at Abdeen Palace.

div.head: THE PRINCESS CASE
div.p: This most interesting lawsuit will he pleaded on Wednesday and Thursday next before the Mined Courts and should be very largely attended. The heirs of Ismail Pacha will he represented by Mes. Vella and Manusardi. The former will plead on Wednefday morning, the latter on Thursday morning, while Me. Pietri, of the Contentieox, who is representing the Government, will be heard on Wednesday afternoon. The oaBe will then be held over for a week, after which the "Miniature publ:que” will give his conclusions.

div.head: MUNICIPALITIES COMMISSION
div.p: The Higher Commission of the Municipalities met on Saturday at the Ministry of the Interior under the presidency of Ibrahim Pasha Neguib, Under Secretary of State. It was decided to connect the Nile bank wiih the shore of the Menzaleh lake at Damietta by a road. The Ministry of Finance has been rtquested to open the necessary credit of L E. 3.600 for the scheme. The Commission also decided to supply the sakkas of Mit Gbamr with artesian well water at a low price.

div.p: The Moss liner Khephren sailed from Liver pool, vifi. Malta, with mails and a ca^go of 23,057 bags onions. The Cunatd S. S. Cypria arrived at Liver pool on Saturday morning. The S. S. Orestes (Westcott and Laurance Line) left Malta on Friday and is due here to-morrow with general cargo frem London. The S. S. Creole Prince, from Alexandria, arrived at Manchester on the 21st inst.

div.head: NATIVE PRESS OPINIONS
div.p: Native Press opinions on the increase of the Army of Ocoopation are decidedly interesting. The ‘ Moayad,” after denying the statement that Gbszi Mukhtar Pacha bad claimed for Turkey the right to construct a line to Suez whioh would place Egypt at the mercy of an Ottoman army, continues : ‘ Now that the pilgrim route has been changed, Tabah becomes of no importance to Egypt and the Suzerain Empire, which has alresdy reoccupied all the posts on the E. side of the Golf of Akaba, wishes to come into possession of Tabah for the same purpose, viz., in the interests of the pilgrims. In our opinion it has every right to do so. We fail to see the threats, on which English newspapers have enlarged, in the Ghazi’s answer. After all, his Excellency is not responsible for the deductions of overexcited journalists. What then is the chief object of this augmentation of our Army of Occupation at a moment when all is profoundly peaoefol in the oountry and Egyptians see in the Tabah question nothing that concerns them deeply, and are ready to agree to any solution of the difficulty ! (The italics are ours). The deoision has then been taken against the Ottoman Empire and not against Egypt and its people The policy is unwise ; it can only draw the attention of Egyptians to something far more important than theactual dispute: The question whether England intends to push the Akaba question to a point where the relations between the two countries would be dangerously strained Is this to England’s advantage ! Can England depend on the Egyptian Government so far in a quarrel over the insignificant post of Tabah ! And can the Egyptian Government follow England to the end ! The “Lewa” is briefly indignant. “Great Britain,” says our contemporary, has decided to reinforce her garrison in Egypt, and yet there is nothing in the oountry to oall for such a deci si id, especially a3 Lord Cromer does not need an army to realise his wishes in the Egyptian Government but does so with the assent of the Egyptian authorities, aud by the issue of the necessary decrees. The reason of the increase is attributable to the occupation of Tabah by the Turks. Whom, then, does England want to threaten ! Is it the Egyptians who, if they are interested in this matter, are so out of a natural sentiment that none can question ? Does she desire thereby to threaten the Ottoman Empire! We know that there is not a Tark who allows himself to be influenced by these threats whioh have no effeot on the policy of the Empire.Does she desire to farther annoy the Egyptians 1 We are in a position to assure her that the Egyptians are driven quite wild abo:t the Ocoupation and that she need not employ fresh methods to attain this end.’’ Of “Al Ahram” we have already spoken. “A I Watan” has devoted two articles to the subject. In the first it remarks: “This increase, like the Occupation, may be useful to us (i.e., the Copts). But England has a reason for this aotion, especially since the present Government has all along opposed any increase of expenditure on the Empire’s military forces.” The article concludes vaguely with the remark that while the Akaba affair has perpaps been the oause of this aotion by H.B.M.’s Government nothing can be defiaitely known. In any case the sudden inorease will be a good lesson. Id a second article “Al Watan” expresses its couviotiou that Lord Cromer is alone responsible for the increase of the British forces in Egyyt, and, unheard of comment, declares that newspapers ought not to lay down the law on subjects on which they know nothing. We had thought that that was their ‘ raison d’etre.” We heartily agree with “Al Watan” in deprecating all blaster against the Turkish High Commissioner which will very likely have the opposite effeot to that intended. The Government will oertainly not follow any such course. “Al Gawareb el Masrieh” says:—“What signification is to be given to the deoision of the British Cabinet to increase the effective of thq British garrison in Egypt ? Who knows the truth! Simple tolk attribute it to a crisis between the Egyptian and Tarkish Governments. Bat th's hypothesis has been refuted by the declarations of the British Foreign Office. Other and wiser heads consider that it is merely an answer to the increase of the Ottoman force at Akaba. This hypothesis is more probable, and if it be correct no one and nothing are the worse for the change—except the Egyptian Treasury. "Germany may be in the background but we know that her intervention is not dangerous for she has before now given ground at the last moment. We therefore request the Ghazi and our own diplomats not to push matters too far and so avoid all unpleasant consequences of the dispute. The Egyptian nation wishes to see no hindrance to the economic development ct the country, which it considers of far greater importance than Tabah and Akaba. Finally, we hope than none of our clever heads will foment troubles here as they did when the Macedonian question was raised and that diplomats of the two countries will be allowed to settle the dispute in a manner advantageous to both sides.”

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HORTICULTURAL EXHIBITION
div.p: The annual exhibition of the Alexandria Horticultural Society was held at San Stefano on Saturday and yesterday, and was on both days visited by large crowds of people, the attendance, we believe, exceeding that of last year. The show was opened as usual by H. H. the Khedive, wLo arrived at the Casir.o with his accustomed punctuality at 4 p.m. on Saturday, accompanied by H. E. the Governor. His Highness was received at the entrance by H. H. Prince Hussein Pacha Kamel, Ad miral Sir Masrie Blomfield, and the other members of the committee, who accompanied the Khedive on his tour of the buildiDg and tents. His Highness evinced the greatest interest in all he saw and after congratulating the committee on the success of their efforts, departed, as he had arrived, attended by the Governor and snite. Immediately after the Khedive’s departure the general public were admitted to view the exhibits. The two principal features of this year’s show were the great interest that was taken in Prince Hussein’s £30 prize pelargoniums aud the enormous number of exhibits of vegetables. The pelargoniums were sufficient in number 1j fill a large tent aud the exhibits of vegetables were over 600 in number. The committee initiated a new movement this year, which was, that on Sunday morniDg they arranged with M. Monfront, the capable gardener of the Municipality, who had been cne of the vegetable judges, to give an object- lesson to the natives in order that the latter should understand how to stage their exhibits* and how to select their vegetables for the show The large ballroom of the Casino was crowded with valuable plants grown in hothouses. In the middle of the room were three groups of oaladiums, in which olass the competition was extremely keen between M. Zsrvudaohi and M. Kindinico. To the ordinary pablio it seemed as if M. Kindinico, who only obtained the second prizi, had the more beautiful collection, but doabtless the judges were influenced in favour of M. Zervudachi because of the faot that the leaves of his plants were finer, and were perhaps grown more according to the ideis of the present day, whioh, we believe, are to withdraw the smaller leaves to give strength to the larger. The four enormoas groups of orotous had a pleasing effect from the variety of thsir leaves. M. Salvago well deserved the first prizd, as the plants were covered with foliage from the bottom of the stems, and were well-grown plants. The three other groups certainly exceeded those of former years, and amongst them the group of Hassan Bey Raspem showed an extraordinarily beauti- fal variety of tints on the leaves. M. E. C. Zervadachi’s large group had the merit of containing several fine plants which we have seen in former years, thereby showing the attention he must pay to his garden in order to keep such specimens as marautha, theo- riums, et?., which require so much oare to keep them in a healthy condition. The Begonia Rex, which are generally such a feature of the Alexandria Show, were somewhat of a disappointment this year; all the usual competitors seemed to have failed from one oause or another with the exception of M. Kindinico, who staged a good group. There was a remarkable exhibit (not for competition) of orchids, shown by Hissan Bey Rassem, placed on a long table, aud near by were the orchids of M. Zarvad one of which was never known to fl iwer before in Egypt So overcrowded was the ballroom that another room had to be requisitioned for the flue palms of M. Salvago, the autheriums of Bartau Bey, and the two fine specimen plants which were placed close to the entrance. A feature of the Alexandria show has always been the enormous groups of palms and zmal pelargoniums. Th se filled almost the whole of the largest tent and were quite equal to former years. The only other exhibit of importance in this tent was a good oolleotioa of carnations, staged by Mme Debbace. The progress which has been made by the Municipality sinoe the gardens were taken over by M. Monfront was shown by the large collection of nearly every kind of annual whioh he staged. In consequence of Prince Hussein having graciously offered an objet d’art of the value of £30, great interest has been taken in pelargoniums. The prize was won by Mr. L. Sanders with forty good plants oovered with flowers of nearly every shade imaginable. The pelargoniums had been well-grown, were staged with effeot, and merited the priz?. Mme Deb- fane was near enough for the jndges to award her a silver medal. Fine collections were also staged by M. Benaohi, M. Salvago, and others. The silver gilt medal offered by the Royal Horticultural Society of London for the best collection of roses as out flowers was awarded to Mr. Sandars, the silver medal going to M. Kindinico. Mrs. Crafton staged the best rose in the Bhow. Mr. Percy Carver always shows a good oolleotion of sweetpeas and as a true amateur of flowers, never fails to give the proper names. He showed two boxes this year, but we are not sure that they were so good as those we saw three years ago. Mrs. Borohgre- vink’s anemones, iris, and large oolleotion of out flowers all won first prizes, and among the new competitors who distinguished themselves were Mrs Borton and Mrs. Richmond. The table decorations this year were not so numerous as usual. Miss Hewat took first prize with a design in yellow roses and dark folisge, Mrs. Magnus the second with an arrangement of red pelargoniums, and Miss G. T. Atkin was highly commended for a table with salmon coloured roses ; but the feature of the room was certainly Miss E. B. Atkin’s original idea of decorating a table as a reminiscence of the first show held at San Stefano. The flowers were plaoed in little

boxes, similar to the boxes in whioh exhibits are shown in the tent of out flawers. The names of the exhibitors were added and the flowers selected were those generally exhibited by the members who gained the prizes. Miss Atkin had even remembered those who generally stage vegetables and she had grouped probably the smallest potatoes, cabbages, asparagas, that have ever been seen at an exhibition. The prettiest vase of flowers was that shown by Mme Zervudaohi with yellow broom, and Miss Hewat obtained two prizes for flowers which had been most artistically arranged. Amongst the vegetables staged by amateurs, the large group shown by Bartau Bay. for which a silver medal was awarded, aud the collection of Mr. F. Haselden well merited attention. The native exhibits oooupied a large amount of space and were certainly an improvement on former years. The following were the judges Pot Plants and Cut Flowers : Messrs. Ebell, Eggert, Ghyselu, Hassan Rausem Bey, Seffer and Tramontina. Table Deoorations: Mesdames Bird, Gesoher, and Peel. Vegetable?: Messrs. Lasoaris, Monfront, and Simond Bey.

div.head: BULLETIN DB LA BOURSE
div.p: (Aujcwrthmi à midi et demie) La matinée a été toute entière oonaaorée anz Port Said Salt Association et aux Salt and Soda. Ces dernière? ont clôturé à 23/3 et les Port Said Salt à 15/3 aobetenrs. Qaant an reste, il y a fléshissement général, excepté ei Agricole qni hausse an contraire à 10 1/8—10 3/16. \ Quelques affaires ont également été traitées en Trust à 1 21/32. L’Oasis (Corporation of Western E*ypt) est invendable à 1 1/4. Da 33/6 la New Egyptian tombe à 31/9 et les Upper Egypt Hotels de 5 3/16 à 4 3/4. ^ * Cette réaction est probablement appelée à s’accentuer bien davantage d’ici à la fin du mois, oar il saffit d’ane vente de 25 titres poor occasionner nne dégringolade, comme cela est arrivé ce matin pour le Crédit Franoo- Egyptien.

div.head: The Port Said Salt Association, Limited
div.p: Les assemblées Extraordinaires et Ordinai res de la Port Said Salt Association, Ltd., ont eu lieu, Samedi, aveo nn concours inusité d’actionnaires. Il y avait plus de 60 actionnaires et 135.000 actions étaient représentées. Les propositions faites par le groope d'actionnaires intéressés dans la Sait Soda, en vue d’amener la fusion des deux Sociétés ont été rejetées à une énorme majorité. L’Assemblée Ordinaire a approuvé le rapport, a décidé de distribuer le dividende de 5 %, a nommé Administrateurs M:M. Vermond et Geo. Sait, en remplacement dés deux administrateurs sortants qni ne se présentaient pas à la réélection et a nommé Mr. Hewat, censeur. A la suite de l’Assemblée, MM. Debourg et R. Abdy administrateurs ont donné leur démission.

div.head: CORRESPONDANCE
div.p: CORRESIWDAflCE Nous ne nommes p«u» reapon*ablM dos opinion* mi par nos correspondants, mais nous désirons, dans un esprit de loyale polémique, permettre—dans certaines limites nécés saires—unellbre discussion.

div.head: PORT SAID SALT ASSOCIATION AND SALT AND SODA COMPANY.
div.p: Monsieur le Directeur de l’Egyptian Gazette L’Assemblée Générale Extraordinaire qui a eu lieu samedi a été très? animée contrairement anx habitudes d’Alexandrie. . C’est l’apologie de la Sait and Soda qui a eu les honneurs de la journée. L’Administrateur Délégué de cette Sooiété a parlé admirablement bieu et rien n’a manqué dans ses arguments pour impressiorner les actionnaires de la Port- Said : désir du Gouvernement pour que la fusion se fasse, ce qui a été contesté ; le Wadi Natroun est une mine d’or, mais pour le mo ment cela ne représente que des espérances ; finalement, et o’est le point important, l’Ad ministrateur Délégué de la Sait and Soda a déolaré que sa Sooiété n’admettant pas une concurrence quelconque avait décidé qu’aussi- tôt que la Port-Said 8alt commencera à vendre du sel dans l’Intérieur, elle vendrait dans les villages son sel au prix des transports de Port-Said dans les diverses villes de l’inférieur, sans olonler la valeur du sel ; que la Sait and Soda aveo l’exploitation des huileries et savon neries, pondre, etc. gagnera environ £35,000 et qu’elle n’avait pas besoin du sel pour donner un dividende à ses actionnaires. Ces déclara rions sont de nature à faire réfléchir les action naires de la Sait and Soda, et oomme tel je trouve que si réellement de telles décisions ont été priée? nos dividendes futurs risquent beaucoup. J’ai sous les yeux le rapport de la Sait and Soda au 31. août 1905 pour 17 moi* d’exercice, et j’y rélève que l’exploitation commerciale des huileries et savonneries, vente du sel. déduorionfaite des frais, a rapporté £52,559. mais je vois de l’autre côté : Salaire?, frais d’dministration etc. — £17,747 Servioe des obligations ... £ 6,604 £24,351 Bénéfices ... ... £28,208 y compris oeux du sel. S’il y a lutte entre les deux Sociétés la Sait and Soda dit poavoir compter sur les bénéfices des huileries qui suivant ce que disait l’administrateur délégué s’élèveront à ... £35/00 je dédois la proportion de 17,745 pour 12 mois £12,546 le servioe des obligations ... £ 6,604 £19,150 Reitent £15,850. Cela suffirait pour donner le 3 % s/ le capital mais comme la vente du sel non seulement ne rapportera rien, et sera au contraire passive de tous les frais généraux incombant à oette branche, frais qui doivent être énorme?, il y a à prévoir que oette évaluation de bénéfices se transformera en perte. Je ne sais ce qae fera la Port Said Salt mais sans rien perdre elle peut jeter sur les mar chés de l’intérieur une certaine quantité de rel afin d’obliger la Sait and Soda à maintenir sa politique de travail à perte, et dans oette lutte je crains bien que ce ne soit le colosse qui doivent finalement céder. Qu’en pensent les actionnaires de la Sait and 8oda ? Un Actionnaire de 14 Salt and Soda. 27778-1

div.head: The Upper Egypt Hotels Company
div.p: MM. les actionnaire? sont informés que le dernier versement de £1 par action est paya- b’e le premier mai 1906. div.head: Municipalité d’Alexandrie.
div.p: AVIS CONCERNANT LES RATS. Cette époque de Tannés ocmoidant avjc la réapparition de la peste, les autorités sanitaires croient devoir rappe’er le rôle prépondérant qne jouent les rats dans la propagation de cette épidémie. Elles engagent les habitants de la Ville et principalement les personnes qni sont parti onlièrement exposées aa oontaot des rats (telles qne bakals, marchand? d’huile, de farine, de savon, propriétaires d’écuries, eto ) à faire asage des ratières et des boulettes empoisonnées que la Municipalité met gratuitement à leur disposition. Les autorité? sanitaires accordent une prime de P.T. 20 pour tout rat qui aura été reconnu atteint, ou seulement suspect de peste. Toutes les toi? qu’on voudra faire parvenir dans ce bat, des rat? au laboratoire, on s’abstiendra de les y apporter eoi-même, mais on les mettra, en les prenant si possible aveo des pinoettes, dans un seau, et Ton préviendra la Municipalité ou l’Hôpital da Gouvernement. L'Administrateur (Signé) W. P. Chatàway. Alexandrie, le 21 Avril 1906. 27769-3 1

div.head: Administration des Chemins de Fer de l’Etat Egyptien.
div.p: .A. "V I S L’Administration des Chemins de fer de l’Etat a l’honneur de porter à la oonnaissai c? du Public qu’à partir du 15 Mai 1906 les arti oies suivants : lèves, blés, maïs, orges, lentilles, helbés, lupins et pois chiches, qni seront transportés par charge complète oa inoomplète de toute? les gares de la Haute-Egypte situées au Sud d’Abou-el-Noamrous (inclusivement) destination des gares de la Basse-Egypte (y compris le Caire, Ghiz?b, Bonlao Daoroar et Embabeh), seront taxé? au taux de la 6me olasse da Tarif Général des Marchandises, avec une rédaction de 25 %. Cette rédaction s’étendra également sur les “Tibns” qni seront expédiés des gares de la Haute-Egypte au Sud d’Abou el-Nomrous (inclusivement) à destination des gares de la Basse Egypte (y compris les sus-mentionnées) par chargement complet (avec un minimum de 6,000 kilogs.) et tans responsabilité pour l’Administration. Ces disposition? seront mises en vigueur jaeqn’au 31 Août 1906 et seront appliquées seu'emeut sur le prix de transport. Las frais acoessoire? seront perças au complet. Le Caire, le 18 Avril 1906. 27763-1

On pourra visiter les dits Meubles, les jours de Vendredi, Samedi et Dimanche les 27, 28 et 29 avril 19 6, de 9 Inureî da mtiu à midi et de 3 à 6 heares de l'après-midi. 277 45-8 1

div.head: Egypt and Levant Steamship
div.p: COMPANY* LIMITED. (To be Incon>or*tôd under the Companies’ Acts, 1861 to l(XXy Capital 9 . . £200,000 Divided into 199,000 Ordinary 8hares of £1 each, and .20,000 Deferred Shares of Is. each. The holders of the Ordinary Shares are eu titled (1) to a fixed cumulative dividend at the rate of 5% per annum on the capital for the timé being paid up or credited as paid up thereon respectively, and to 60% of the surplus profits which in each year it Bhall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining 4after paying or providing for the payment of the said fixed cumulative dividend ; (2), to priority as to return of capital and payment off of arrears of dividend whether declared or not up to the oommenoement of the winding up. „ The Deferred Shares confer on the holders thereof rateably and in proportion to the num- ber of Deferred Shares held by them respec- tively the right to 4% of the surplus profits which in respect of each year it shall from time to time be determined to distribute remaining after paying or providing for the payment of the said fixed onmnlative dividend on the Ordinary Share j. Of the above 199,000 Ordinary Shares, $0,000 are payable * as part of the Parohase- Money as mentioned herein, and 61,000 will be reserved tor private subscription. Subscriptions are invited from the public at par for 75,000 Ordinary Share!. Payable 10% on Application, 15% oa Allot- ment, 25% On the 15th Judo, 1906. and the balance, viz., 50%, on the 15th July, 1906. Shire Warrants to Bearer will be delivered free of stamp duty to Original Subscribers upon payment of their Shares in full, but no payment in anticipation will carry with it any right to dividend on the amoont so paid in advance. Secretary and London Offices t John William Stranghan, 8, LeadenhaU Street, London, E.C. Managers t X, Bowen Rees A Co., Ltd., Smyrna. AQSnte In Alexandria t Messrs. Barker A Co. PROSPECTUS- This Company has been formed for the pur- pose specified in the Memorandum of Associa- tion and in particular (1) to take over and acquire the good will and business of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., together with the existing fleet cf steamers of the Com- pany, consisting of fonr steamers of large car- rying capacity. (2) To acquire and/or bnild new steamers or other vessels. (3) To ontinne and develop the trade which has been carried on for the last 14 years by the Talbot Steam- ship Company between Smyrna and other Levant ports, Egypt and the Uiited Kingdom, (4) Generally to carry on the business of ship- owners in all its branches in the same or other parts of the world. It is considered by the Directors of thi* company that the present is a favourable n. ornent for extending the shipping business already developed by the Talbot Steamship Company, more particularly as there is every probability of there being favourable oppor- tunity of acqoiring new tonnage at low cost. The Talbot Steamship Company has always enjoyed a high repntatibn in the Levant and has financially stood on a sound bassis ; like other shipping concerns, its profits have been affected at times by depression in freights, but bad and good years taken together the average net earnings over the whole period of its existence have been very satisfactory, in spite of heavy management charges, which, under the new arrangement, will be considerably reduced. The volume of trade has so increased that additions to the fleet are absolutely necessary. Th shares of the Talbot Steamship Company, Ltd., are held in very few hands, «nd instead of further increasing its capital it has been determined to make over its present baiiuees and steamers to this company. it is proposed to build, or, if a favourable opportunity offers, boy at once four new steamers, which, fitted with all the latest appliaLces, would be run on the most econo- mical lines as to coal consumption, cost of working, etc. It is confidently expected that with an increased fleet and facilities the new Company will at once take quite a leading position in the Levant as shipowners and command a steadily increasing clientèle amongst shippers. The four steamers and their tackle, apparel, etc., to be taken over from the Talbot Steam ship Company, Ltd., have been valued by the
